station.name: PSYCHOBILLY
station.longDesc: Saykobilli (English Psychobilly) is a genre of rock music that combines the expression and aggressiveness of punk rock with country and rockabilly melodies. According to the American critic Jen Kaminsky, the genre of “cyclobili” unites all modern and post-punk rockabilly types (such as gotabilly, pankabilli, surfabilli, crastabilly, thrasabilly, etc.) As a rule, instead of a bass guitar, a bass bass (continuity with rockabilly) is used in psychobilly groups.

station.name: INDIE/TWEE POP
station.longDesc: Indie Pop, in the United States also Twi-Pop, was an alternative rock style that developed in the mid-80s of the 20th century, usually called Scottish post-punk bands, published on Postcard Records - Orange Juice, Josef K, etc. .: This music, deprived of the usual for punk rock and post-punk depression and aggression, was simple, melodic and 'positive'.

station.name: FOLK ROCK
station.longDesc: Folk-rock (eng. Folk rock) - a musical genre that combines elements of folk and rock. In the original and narrowest sense, the term

refers to the genre formed in the United States and Great Britain in the mid-1960s. The pioneer of the genre is the band The Byrds from Los Angeles, which begins to perform traditional folk music and songs by Bob Dylan in typical rock instrumentation, strongly influenced by The Beatles and other British groups.

station.name: ROCK&ROLL
station.longDesc: Rock and roll (from the English. Rock and roll or rock'n'roll) - a genre of popular music, which became widespread in the mid-1950s. Formed from a combination of elements of African-American and 'white' genres, like rhythm and blues and country. The style of white performers was also called rockabilly.

station.name: HARD ROCK
station.longDesc: Hard rock (English hard rock, literally hard rock or hard rock) is a genre of rock music, characterized by the highlighted role of the so-called. rhythm section, mainly bass and percussion instruments. Compositions of this genre are often built on riffs in figures with a size of 4/4. Hard rock was born in the 1960s, took on its usual forms in the late 1960s - early 1970s, and it flourished in the early 1970s, with the participation of bands such as Led Zeppelin, Deep Purple and Black Sabbath.

station.name: RUSSIAN ROCK/BARD ROCK
station.longDesc: Russian rock is rock music from Russia or in Russian. Russian rock originated in the USSR in the second half of the 20th century under the influence of world, especially Western, music, and still exists in Russia and the CIS countries.

station.name: GLAM ROCK/METAL
station.longDesc: Glam rock (from Glam rock, from glamorous - “spectacular”) is a genre of rock music that originated in the UK in the very beginning of the 1970s. and became one of the dominant genres of the first half of that decade. Glam rock performers were characterized by a vivid image, expressed through theatrical showiness of exotic costumes, abundant use of makeup, androgynous appearance. Musically, glam rock was heterogeneous, combining rock and roll, hard rock, art rock and pop. Elements of the glam rock style had a significant impact on disco, punk, new wave.

station.name: INSTRUMENTAL ROCK
station.longDesc: Instrumental rock is a genre of rock music, in which music prevails, not vocals. It was most popular in the 1950s and 1960s. Examples of instrumental rock can be found in almost any genre. Most influential on instrumental rock are the following performers: Joe Satriani, Steve Vai, Link Rey, Eric Johnson, Chuck Berry, Surfaris, Dick Dale, The Ventures, The Shadows, Jeff Beck, Jennifer Batten, Paul Gilbert, Les Fradkin, Booker T and the MGs, The Champs and Frank Zappa.

station.name: DREAM POP
station.longDesc: Dream-pop is an alternative rock style formed in the early 1980s at the junction of post-punk and ethereal. Dream pop is characterized by atmospheric, “dreamy” sound, combined with “airy”, gentle pop melodies. The founders of this style is the Scottish band Cocteau Twins, published on the iconic 4AD label, which later collaborated with many dream-pop bands. In the late 1980s, musical directions such as shugaying and British space rock developed on the basis of dream-pop.

station.name: J-ROCK (JAPANESE ROCK)
station.longDesc: J-Rock (jap. Dzeirokku, Japanese rock) - a generalized name for the directions of rock music, common in Japan. Often confused with Visual kei, which is incorrect, since the second is a subgenre of the first. It is often used to refer to all directions in Japan as a whole, but sometimes J-metal, J-punk and J-ska are also popular for Japanese groups of these directions.

station.name: JAZZ ROCK
station.longDesc: Jazz-rock (English - jazz rock). This concept can be attributed to the loudest, fiercest and electrified fusion ensembles from the jazz camp, but more often it describes those performers who are on the fatal side of the equation. Jazz-rock first appeared in the late 60s as an attempt to combine the unbridled power of rock with musical complexity and fiery improvisations of jazz.

station.name: PROGRESSIVE ROCK
station.longDesc: Progressive rock (also known as prog rock, progressive and prog, Eng. Progressive rock) is a style of rock music characterized by the complication of musical forms and creative enrichment of rock through dialogue with other areas of musical art (academic music, jazz, folk music (European and eastern) and avant-garde). We can say that in terms of synthesis with other directions, progressive rock for rock music is analogous to fusion for jazz.

station.name: NOISE ROCK
station.longDesc: Noise-rock (eng. Noise rock) - a musical genre, style of rock music, referring to its experimental and alternative branches; emerged in the 1980s as a more avant-garde and radical branch of punk rock. Noise-rock was formed as a result of mixing punk with the atonal noise characteristic of early industrial and noise and the use of dissonant guitar sound and (often) unconventional song structure.

station.name: CROSSOVER PROG
station.longDesc: At its core, Crossover prog is a concession to fashion trends or, more simply, introducing elements of popular music into progressive music. In this case, the music remains with the elements of the program, but uses some simplified forms inherent in pop music. This state of affairs can also be partially regarded as mainstream- a current when the group lost its individuality and became “one of”.

station.name: PIANO ROCK/POP
station.longDesc: Variety of alternative rock, as well as the style of popular music, which is based on the piano, and sometimes on piano-related keyboard instruments. Traditionally, piano rock, sometimes called “piano pop,” was not as common as classical rock, however, modern artists such as: Keane, The Fray, The Script, Augustana, Coldplay, OneRepublic, Muse contributed to the popularization of the genre.

station.name: SLOWCORE/SADCORE
station.longDesc: Sedkore (Eng. Sadcore) or Slowcore (Eng. Slowcore) is a sub-style in alternative and indie rock, which is characterized by
melodies with minimalist arrangements, sad or gloomy texts, melancholic, depressive mood.

station.name: ETHEREAL WAVE
station.longDesc: Ethereal Wave (born ethereal wave is an ethereal wave) or ethereal darkwave, ethereal-goth, and also simply ethereal-sub genre of darkwave, which is characterized differently by “gothic”, “romantic” or “otherworldly” sound. Ethereal appeared in the UK in the early 1980s, as a result of the development of gothic rock, was represented mainly by performers from the label 4AD, such as Cocteau Twins and the early Dead Can Dance.

station.name: SURF ROCK
station.longDesc: Surf (surf-rock, surf-pop, English surf rock, surf pop, surf music) is popular American music from the early 60s of the 20th century, originally beach music, that is, for resort visitors and especially for surfers. The music is mainly instrumental, the beginning of the surf is considered to be the original guitar style of Dick Dale (born Dick Dale), from which it all began.

station.name: PSYCHEDELIC ROCK
station.longDesc: Psychedelic Rock (eng. Psychedelic Rock) - a musical genre that emerged in the mid-60s in Western Europe and California (San Francisco and Los Angeles). Psychedelic rock is associated with the concepts of 'psychedelia' and 'psychedelics' (hallucinogens). He also has a close relationship with the hippie subculture and Eastern (Indian) philosophy.

station.name: DARK WAVE
station.longDesc: Darkwave (dark wave- “dark wave”) is a musical style, one of the directions on the gothic scene, a combination of electronic, industrial-experimental and neoclassical music.

station.name: PUNK ROCK
station.longDesc: Punk rock (English punk rock) - a genre of rock music, which arose in the early 1970s in the United States and, a little later, in the UK. The sense that early punk rock bands put into their genre was the desire to play, dominating the ability to do so; Thanks to this definition, a diverse early American punk scene has been formed, ranging from the lightweight Ramones to the complex and experimental Television.

station.name: GRUNGE
station.longDesc: Grunge (born Grunge, letters. Dirt) is also known as Seattle sound - a sub-style alternative rock that developed from hardcore punk in the mid-1980s in the US state of Washington, primarily in Seattle. Grange is characterized by “dirty” guitar sound, an abundance of distortion, contrasting dynamics with “loud-quiet” alternation, gloomy texts on the subject of alienation, loneliness and apathy.

station.name: BRITPOP
station.longDesc: Britpop - a genre of alternative rock, the revival of the dominant guitar style of pop music of the 60s on the UK music scene in the 90s. The style is characterized by the uncompromising “Britishness” of melodies and sound, using British traditions of both folk and rock and roll music of the 60s - 70s of the XX century.

station.name: NEW WAVE
station.longDesc: New Wave (eng. New Wave) - musical direction; this term refers to various genres of rock music that emerged in the late 1970s and early 1980s and that they broke off stylistically and ideologically from previous genres of rock. The term
was quite controversial. At first, the concept classified the genre of rock music from the early 1970s by such groups as Velvet Underground and New York Dolls.

station.name: ART ROCK
station.longDesc: Art rock (eng. Art rock) - the direction of rock music, which is characterized by melodic, harmonic or rhythmic experiments, as well as a large number of artistic images in the lyrics. Art-rock often goes beyond the forms and genres of modern popular music in the direction of jazz, academic, ethnic music or experimental avant-garde.

station.name: GOTHIC ROCK
station.longDesc: Gothic rock (English gothic rock) - a musical genre that arose as a branch of post-punk at the turn of the 1970s and 1980s. In the early 1980s, the genre became a separate direction. The music is dominated by dark themes and intellectual trends, such as romanticism, nihilism, as well as the Gothic trend in the art of the New Age.

station.name: POST GRUNGE
station.longDesc: Post-grunge (English Post-grunge) is an alternative music style that came out of grunge and became quite widespread on the big stage after 1994. The principal difference from the grunge is a softer sound, pre-calculated for convenient broadcasting. Many postgrange groups often change the direction of music from grunge to pop-rock, pop-punk or alternative metal.

station.name: GARAGE ROCK
station.longDesc: Garage rock (eng. Garage rock) - a genre of rock music, formed in the United States and Canada in the 1960s. It is considered the main forerunner of punk rock and an important part of proto-punk.

station.name: OI!/STREET PUNK
station.longDesc: Oi! (Oh!) - The musical direction that emerged in England in the late seventies as an offshoot of punk rock, designed to return the latter to its true, proletarian roots.

station.name: HORROR PUNK
station.longDesc: Horror punk (born Horror punk) is a sub-genre of punk rock that appeared in the USA in the late 1970s to form The Misfits, and mixes texts and image derived from sci-fi and horror films with early musical punk rock, doo-wopa and, to a lesser extent, rockabilly.

station.name: ECLECTIC PROG
station.longDesc: In relation to progressive music, the term “eclectic” describes the summation of elements introduced from various styles, trends, trends and genres (and not only musical ones). Progressive music itself can be defined as eclectic, in relation to rock music in general. Nevertheless, in defining a number of groups in this category, the factors of their exclusivity play a role, even in this genre.

station.name: HEAVY/HARD PSYCHEDELIC
station.longDesc: Heavy Psychedelic (eng. Heavy Psychedelic, Heavy Psych) - the direction of rock music, which originated in the late 1960s. Heavy Psych was a product of the nebulous era of Psychedelic Rock, which adopted the Blues Rock musical tendencies of the scene: heavy riffs and improvisation, together with an increased level of severity of the sound of 'dense' fuzzy guitars that created a harsh, gloomy atmosphere.

station.name: CHRISTIAN ROCK
station.longDesc: Christian rock (English Christian rock) - a type of rock music, dedicated to the theme of Christianity. Christian rock bands sing songs about God, faith, and soul, and usually consist of church christians. Christian rock stands out exclusively for the lyrics, it does not have its own musical characteristics and can be performed in the most diverse styles of rock music.

station.name: DANCE/DISCO/FUNK PUNK
station.longDesc: Dance Punk, Fun Punk or Disco Punk (Eng. Dance Punk, Funk Punk, Disco Punk) is a musical genre that emerged in the late 1970s and is closely associated with post punk and new wave.

station.name: ROCKABILLY
station.longDesc: Rockabilly (born rockabilly) - a musical genre, a kind of rock and roll, which appeared in the 1950s. In essence, rockabilly is the progenitor of modern rock. The term
comes from the words
and
(one of the names of country music). Rockabilly has roots in country and blues and is focused on the white audience.

station.name: STONER ROCK
station.longDesc: From the beginning to the mid-1990s, a number of Californian groups developed a genre, later called Stoner Rock. Kyuss's Blues for the Red Sun album was released in 1992 and was often viewed as the first stoner rock / metal album. Critics hailed him as an important milestone in hard music.

station.name: AOR/MELODIC HARD ROCK
station.longDesc: AOR (stands for Album-oriented Rock - “album-oriented rock”) is a format of mainstream American FM radio stations with a focus on tracks from album rock artists.

station.name: ROCK/METAL BALLADS
station.longDesc: Rock ballad (born rock ballad; in English also used the name power ballad) - a type of song in rock music, which is a slow, melodic lyric composition. Ballads are often recorded using acoustic guitars and / or piano (as a result of which there are a large number of cover versions for ballads), sometimes electric guitars enter the final part of the song. Percussion parts in ballads may be absent or play a minor role.

station.name: BLUES ROCK
station.longDesc: Blues-rock (English Blues-rock) - a hybrid music genre, a type of rock music that combines elements of the styles blues and rock and roll. The blues-rock sound is based on an electric guitar, a bass guitar and a drum kit, and the sound of an electric guitar is subject to distortion “overdrive”, usually with the help of a tube guitar amplifier.

station.name: RUSSIAN PUNK ROCK
station.longDesc: In the USSR, something similar to punk rock originated in 1979 not only in Leningrad with the creation of the group of Andrey Panov “Automatic Satisfaction”, at some time the project was called 600, but also in the Baltic States (“JMKE”, “Propeller”, “ Velikije Luki ”) and Siberia (Nick Rock and Roll”), and quite unexpectedly in the Crimea (“Second Echelon”, Yuriy Yux), almost simultaneously.

station.name: SYMPHONIC ROCK
station.longDesc: Symphonic rock (eng. Symphonic rock, Symphonic Prog) - style of rock music, a subgenre of progressive rock. The term was proposed to refer to progressive groups that are more oriented towards an academic approach to music, in contrast to experimental and psychedelic groups.

station.name: SOUTHERN ROCK/METAL
station.longDesc: Southern Rock (southern rock, 'southern rock') - a subgenre of rock music that emerged in the southern United States, was popular in the 1970s. It should be noted that the origins of rock music lie mainly in the musicians of the southern United States, in particular, Elvis Presley, Little Richard, Bo Diddley, Jerry Lee Lewis and many other rock and roll artists came from the southern United States.

station.name: POST ROCK
station.longDesc: Post-rock (English Post rock) - an experimental genre of rock music, which is characterized by the use of instruments associated with rock music, as well as rhythm, melodies, timbre and chord sequence, which are not typical for traditional rock. Representatives of the genre mainly play instrumental music. Post-rock music combines elements of various musical genres, such as ambient, jazz, electronic music, rock.

station.name: SHOEGAZING
station.longDesc: Shoegizing (or Shugeyz) (English shoegazing (shoegaze) - one of the genres of alternative rock (indie rock), originated in the late 80's. The term was coined by journalists of the British music press NME and Melody Maker and described the style of behavior of musicians during live performances that were originally a kind of mockery of non-charismatic musicians who did not make colorful shows but, on the contrary, behaved detached, passive and apathetic.

station.name: NEO-PROGRESSIVE ROCK
station.longDesc: Neo-prog (eng. Neo-progressive rock, neo-prog) is a style of rock music that appeared at the very end of the 70s. This sub-style of progressive rock appeared in the late 1970s, the first wave of neo-prog is music based on the ideas of the most popular art-rock bands of the seventies - Genesis, Pink Floyd, Camel, Rush and others.

station.name: INDUSTRIAL ROCK
station.longDesc: Industrial rock (from the English. Industrial rock - industrial rock) - a musical genre that combines elements of industrial with various subgenres of rock music.

station.name: CHAMBER/BAROQUE/POP/ROCK
station.longDesc: Chambers pop (or Chamber pop) or orc pop (Ork pop), abbr. Form from orchestral pop) - rock music style, characterized by an emphasis on melody and texture, abundant use of string, wind, piano, vocal harmonies and other elements from the lounge and orchestral pop music of the 1960s.

station.name: HEAVY PROG
station.longDesc: It’s probably impossible to define the term “Heavy Prog” precisely. Moreover, many music publications and some music critics generally ignore this term, using only the definitions of 'hard rock' or 'prog rock' in relation to groups belonging to this category.

station.name: DARK CABARET
station.longDesc: Dark Cabaret (born dark cabaret) is a musical genre based on experiments with the sound of a German cabaret of the 1920s. Typical instruments for dark cabaret- piano, violin, cello and other instruments similar in sound to the accordion and trumpet.

station.name: PROGRESSIVE FOLK
station.longDesc: Progressive folk (English Progressive folk) or simply prog folk music genre, which was originally a politicized type of American folk music. In Great Britain, the term “prog-folk” was applied to traditional folk music played with any stylistic or thematic innovations.

station.name: SPACE ROCK
station.longDesc: Space-rock (born Space rock) - a musical genre. Originally, the music of the British progressive and psychedelic groups of the late 1960s - 1970s, such as Hawkwind and Pink Floyd, was so called.

station.name: RUSSIAN FOLK ROCK
station.longDesc: Folk-rock performers in Russia combine elements of rock music with both Russian folk music and the music of Celtic, northern peoples, as well as the peoples of Russia. An example would be the groups Yat-ha and Sak-Sok, performing respectively Tuvan and Tatar folk music based on rock music.

station.name: ALTERNATIVE ROCK
station.longDesc: Alternative rock (English. Alternative rock) - a term in modern music, which is understood as various styles of rock music, opposing traditional. The term appeared in the 1980s. and encompassed many styles that originated in punk rock, post-punk, etc. Currently, alternative rock is divided into two stages: the first is the bands of the 1980s.

station.name: POP ROCK
station.longDesc: Pop-rock (eng. Pop rock, Pop 'N' Rock) - a genre of music that combines elements of pop music and rock music. The songs are characterized by a simple structure, memorable melodies, repetition of musical phrases (from the pop), using electric guitars and drums as the main instruments, and aggressive mood (from the rock).

station.name: INDIE ROCK
station.longDesc: Indie rock (English Indie rock) - a genre of alternative rock, existing mainly in the underground, in an independent information and commercial space. It takes its name from the English word 'Independent'. This is not a peculiar separate style of music, but a generic term for a wide range of musicians and styles, combined with involvement in the underground, counterculture, and having some relation to rock music.

station.name: CLASSIC ROCK/ROCK
station.longDesc: Rock music (eng. Rock music) is a generalized name for a number of popular music trends. The word “rock” - download - in this case indicates the rhythmic sensations characteristic of these areas associated with a particular form of movement, by analogy with “roll”, “twist”, “swing”, “shake”, etc.

station.name: POST PUNK
station.longDesc: Postpunk (English post-punk) - a genre of rock music that emerged in the late 1970s in the UK as a continuation of punk rock. In contrast to the latter, post-punk was distinguished by a wide variety of musical expression due to a wide range of influences on the genre.

station.name: POP PUNK
station.longDesc: Pop punk (English Pop Punk) is one of the basic sub-genres of punk rock, characterized by a mixture of principles and instrumental section of typical punk rock with soft pop melodies and pop music techniques (as well as other
genres). Having appeared along with punk rock, pop-punk experienced a “new birth” and the largest (for punk rock in general) commercial success in the 90s.

station.name: COUNTRY ROCK
station.longDesc: Country rock (eng. Country rock) is a musical genre that combines rock and country music. Country music has always been part of rock and roll since Elvis Presley performed at the Grand Ole Opry in 1955. He played a rhythmic mix of country music and rhythm and blues, nowadays it is called rockabilly - this is an early form rock and roll with a strong country influence.

station.name: KRAUTROCK
station.longDesc: Kraut-rock (him. Krautrock) - the direction of experimental and psychedelic rock music, which arose in the late 1960s - early 1970s in West Germany. The mix of rock music performed on standard rock group instruments (electric guitar, bass guitar, drums, synthesizer), with electronic music structures, as well as electronic sound processing, became the business card of the style.

station.name: INDIE FOLK
station.longDesc: Indie Folk (English Indie folk, independent folk music) is a musical genre created in the 1990s by singer-songwriters from indie rock community influenced by pop folk music of the 50s, 60s and early 70s. s, country music and indie rock.

station.name: MATH ROCK
station.longDesc: Mathematical rock (eng. Math rock) - the direction of rock music, which arose in the late 1980s in the United States. Mathematical rock is characterized by a complex, atypical rhythmic structure and dynamics, sharp, often inharmonious riffs.

station.name: AVANT-PROG/ROCK IN OPPOSITION (RIO)/CANTERBURY SCENE/ZEUHL
station.longDesc: Avant-Prog (English Avant-Prog) is a style of rock music that appeared in the late 1970s as an extension of two separate prog-rock sub-styles: Rock in Opposition (RIO) and Canterbury.

station.name: TWIST
station.longDesc: The twist appeared in 1960 thanks to the American singer Chubby Checker, who sang the song “The Twist” by X. Ballard (Eng.) (1959) and offered a new version of the dance to this song. Became known for the performances of Chubby Checker on Dick Clark television shows. It was widely spread among young people in many countries of the world in the 1970s.

station.name: PSYCHEDELIC FOLK
station.longDesc: Psychedelic folk (born Psychedelic folk) or psycho folk (born psych folk) is a musical genre that emerged in the 1960s at the junction of progressive folk and psychedelic rock. From folk, the genre took on acoustic sound, and from psychedelic rock, elements characteristic of psychedelic music as a whole.
